title: The Arch: Engineering That Changed Everything
description: A fast breakdown of The Arch: Engineering That Changed Everything for builders.

hook.text: The Romans didnâ€™t invent the arch. But they perfected it and used it to build an empire of aqueducts and colosseums.

buildup.text: An arch distributes weight outward into its supports. This lets a span carry far more than a flat beam ever could.

discovery.text: The keystone at the top locks everything in place. Remove it and the entire arch collapses instantly.

twist.text: Ancient arches used no mortar. Gravity and precise stone-cutting held them together for millennia.

climax.text: The Pont du Gard aqueduct in France still stands after 2,000 years. It carried water using only gravity and arches.

punchline.text: The arch turned stoneâ€™s weakness into its greatest strength.

quiz.question: What role does the keystone play in an arch?
options: It locks all the stones in place by distributing weight outward
It is purely decorative and can be removed safely
It supports the arch from below like a column
